provenance.note: Acquired, and probably commissioned, from Blake by Thomas Butts, c. 1799; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; William Michael Rossetti by 1863; William Bell Scott by 1876, sold from his collection Sotheby's, 14 July 1892, lot 238 (£27 to the dealer Bernard Quaritch); offered by Quaritch, *Rough List* no. 127 of August 1892, item 916 (£36), and *Miscellaneous Catalogue* no. 62 of 1893, no item no. (£36); sold 9 May 1893 to E. H. van Ingen acting for Mrs. William Emerson and sold from her collection Sotheby's, 19 May 1958, lot 12 (£1300 to the dealer Thomas Agnew & Sons acting for Gwen, Lady Melchett); sold from Melchett's collection, Christie's, 9 Nov. 1971, lot 71 (£5250 to Piccadilly Gallery); sold by Piccadilly Gallery to the Galleria Galatea, Turin, Italy, by whom sold to a private collector, Milan, Italy. On the market through Nicholas Lott of Larkhall Fine Art, Bath, in Nov. 2013; present whereabouts unknown but possibly still in the private collection in Milan.

objnote.p: The Hebrew letters on the scroll held by the angel are now worn and difficult to interpret. They would seem to represent the idea of a Hebrew inscription without actually being an intelligible text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The figures of St. Matthew and the angel fill this design. St. Matthew stands in front of but is shorter than his companion; the angel's head and shoulders are visible above Matthew's head. The angel stands facing forward, but turns his head slightly left and tilts it down. His enormous wings are folded but spread to either side of his body. He extends his slightly bent right arm down to the left at 45 degrees, and grasps one end of a scroll with his raised right hand. His left hand holds the other side of the scroll, and is visible just below Matthew's raised hands. The angel seems to be nude, and has short curly hair. Light surrounds his head and upper body, forming a halo or kind of mandorla. The angel holds the scroll open in front of Matthew, who bends his head to read the lines of Hebrew text visible on the scroll's surface. St. Matthew stands in a semi-crouched position facing left. His shoulders are slightly hunched. His left arm is by his side, drawn forward slightly and bent across his torso at the elbow. His raised left hand is open, with the fingers spread and the vertical palm facing away. His right hand is also raised in front of his chest, and mirrors the left in position. These hand gestures and his open mouth suggest surprise. His bent left leg is forward. The shape of his garments suggests that his right leg is also bent and extended backwards. He wears a long gown, belted at a high waistline. His left foot emerges from beneath its folds. He has a beard and short curly hair. Its color suggests his age. To either side of Matthew's lower body, but especially on the left, the angel's light reveals the bricks in a wall, or possibly an altar, behind the figures. Dark shadow surrounds Matthew and the angel, stretching to the edges of the design on the bottom and the left and right sides. The design is not based on any specific passage in the gospel of Matthew.
